text: before they can play the children must
learn to fight the only martial arts
academy in Hazara town is full of young
boys and girls who are training to make
themselves physically and mentally
strong every child at the academy has
been directly affected by extremism and
persecution despite limited resources
many and the Academy have won gold and
silver for Pakistan at international
events but more than the awards they
come here to battle a feeling of
powerlessness Yahara community may
Harbor Chico are budgeted every young
boy and girl in our community is sent
here for self-defense we teach them that
they are not victims they can fight back
against their conditions by learning
these skills Samara is only 14 but
already knows too much about loss her
father was kidnapped from outside their
house two years ago allegedly by
militants Samara says no government
official was willing to help find him
now her mother works as a maid to feed
the family and Samara trains to make
herself stronger no one helped us when
we needed it it makes me so angry is it
because we are Hazara why wouldn't
anyone help us
I learned karate because I want to show
the world that girls are not weak
experts say young people in the Hazara
community are under severe psychological
strain at least 1000 people have been
killed by unknown assailants over the
past few years
religion is a factor as they're a
minority Shia community in a
predominantly Sunni Muslim nation as
threats and attacks have increased they
have been moved from the city centre the
authorities say it's for their own
protection the Hazara Shias limited to
get to like areas on the very edges of
Quetta as you can see in front of them
the mountain ranges behind them a city
in which they cannot move around freely
the sense of entrapment is growing
stronger but their children have found a
way have found many ways in fact to
break free to find their identity
see and to be heard the Hazara Parker
boys don't want the way to see them as
victims their performances have gone
viral on social media and they have
followers from around the world but no
one knows them at home despite being the
only group in Pakistan to practice
parkour they have no support even if we
are limited through these two areas like
we are in a resin camp we want to show
that we can still make our country proud
of us
these boys say they no longer feel
trapped because they have found a way to
be who they are to free themselves from
the reality of the Pakistan they live in
they say their hard work and their
dreams will one day help them soar above
the circumstances Sabbath is ours BBC
News quitter
